abstract: This paper studies the interaction between capital reallocation and business cycles. Capital reallocation is pro-cyclical and leads to variations in measured aggregate productivity. Using a simulated method of moments approach, different sources of aggregate fluctuations are studied to assess their ability to match both capital reallocation and business cycle moments. A model economy driven by exogenous variations in the distribution of reallocation costs does remarkably well in matching these moments. These shocks induce changes in capital reallocation and cause endogenous variations in the Solow residual. Analytically a higher-order moment is needed to solve the model accurately and is an integral component connecting reallocation with aggregate productivity.
